title: How Exam Tenders Are Being Twisted in India
content:
Government recruitment exams shape the lives of millions. A recent pattern of tender manipulation and relaxed rules has raised serious concerns about the integrity of the system.

At the center of this story is a relatively small company — Eduquity — whose rapid rise has been closely tied to repeated rule changes and tender cancellations across multiple states and agencies.

1. How the System Reached This Point

The SSC was meant to create a stable, reliable exam ecosystem. Instead, it became vulnerable due to the absence of constitutional safeguards.

1950–1977: UPSC and SSC formed. UPSC gets constitutional protection; SSC does not.
2013–2018: Major leaks → shift to Computer Based Tests → initial failures → TCS stabilizes exams.
2020 onward: Eduquity begins appearing in tenders after repeated rule relaxations.

2. Eduquity’s Rapid Rise

Eduquity’s turnover jumped from around ₹7 crore (COVID period) to over ₹134 crore by 2023. This growth strongly aligns with tenders where criteria were modified soon after Eduquity became ineligible.

The Pattern:
  • Tenders were cancelled when Eduquity didn’t qualify.
  • Reissued tenders had relaxed rules that suddenly made Eduquity eligible.

3. How Tender Rules Were Relaxed

Across SSC, NTA, and MPESB, rule changes consistently favored specific vendors. The table below simplifies the impact.

Criteria Before (Strict) After (Relaxed) Impact
Turnover ₹50 crore (3-year avg.) ₹10 crore (or flexible) Made eligible financially
IT Staff 500 Staff 251 Staff Qualified for full marks
Exam Capacity 1,00,000 candidates 35,000 candidates Met reduced threshold
CMMI Cert Level 5 (Dev & Services) Services only Removed advantage of large firms
Subcontracting Not allowed Allowed ("Ancillary") Enabled outsourcing core tasks

4. The Fallout

Once the transition occurred, candidates across India reported recurring issues:

  • ❌ Frozen screens and server crashes
  • ❌ Question papers failing to load
  • ❌ Exam centers in remote or poorly equipped locations
  • ❌ Suspected paper leaks with images matching official answer keys

5. Why SSC Is Easily Manipulated

Unlike UPSC, SSC has no constitutional protection. This makes it vulnerable to political influence, opaque scoring, and the selection of the lowest financial bidder over the most reliable one.

Example: Eduquity won SSC’s tender at ₹171 per candidate while TCS bid ₹311 — a huge difference, but potentially at the cost of quality and stability.

8. What Must Change

  1. Restore strict tender criteria (Turnover, Staffing, CMMI).
  2. Ban subcontracting of core exam services.
  3. Make technical scores and committee details public.
  4. Give SSC stronger statutory protection.
  5. Publish post-exam audit reports.

Conclusion: Without structural reforms, exam irregularities will continue, trust will erode, and students will pay the price.
author: Vakaalat Team
